asked the Minister for Education the number of secondary and vocational schools which have undergone any of the following forms of rationalisation since the 1980-81 school year, (a) secondary school closure; (b) secondary school amalgamation with vocational school to become community school; (c) secondary school amalgamation with vocational schools to become community college; (d) secondary school assimilation into VEC system as community college; (e) vocational school closure; (f) secondary school alone becoming a community school; (g) vocational school alone becoming a community school; and (h) vocational school becoming a secondary school.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke)
Speaker.P: The information is as follows:—(a) secondary school closures, 9; (b) secondary school amalgamation with vocational school to become a community school, 1; (c) secondary school amalgamation with vocational school to become a community college, 1; (d) secondary school assimilation into VEC system as community college, none; (One secondary school has, however, been absorbed into a vocational school and one secondary school has become a vocational school.) (e) vocational school closures, 4; (f) seconday school alone becoming a community school, 2; (g) vocational school along becoming a community school, none; (h) vocational school becoming a secondary school, none.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Employment of Substitute Teachers.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the circumstances in which substitute teachers are paid in cases of the absence of permanent teachers in secondary, community/comprehensive and VEC second level schools.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke)
Speaker.P: In the case of secondary teachers the payment of substitute teachers is allowed by my Department when permanent teachers are absent on certified sick leave, maternity leave or when acting as examiners at the Department's oral examinations.

It will be appreciated that it is not feasible to indicate each and every kind of situation in which paid substitution may or may not be allowed. Apart from the absences referred to above paid substitution is not sanctioned unless it is established to the Department's satisfaction that alternative arrangements connot suitably and reasonably be made.

In the case of VEC second level schools the position is that teachers are paid salary by the VECs by which they are employed. It is not feasible to indicate each and every kind of situation in which paid substitution may or may not be allowed. In 1978 my Department issued detailed guidelines to the VECs and to the Teachers' Union of Ireland on the question of the employment of substitute teachers in vocational schools. A copy of the guidelines can be supplied if desired. The same guidelines, in general, apply in regard to substitute teachers in community and comprehensive schools as apply in vocational schools.

asked the Minister for Education if she receives copies of timetables showing all data such as times of classes, subjects taught, teachers and subject periods, from secondary community/comprehensive and second level vocational schools.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke)
Speaker.P: Vocational schools and secondary schools are required to complete and forward to my Department in September each year timetable forms showing the data referred to in the question. Such data are not currently received in relation to community/comprehensive schools.

asked the Minister for Education the composition of post-primary course committees; the levels of expenses available to the different categories of persons involved in such committees including substitution arrangements where these exist.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke)
Speaker.P: The composition of post-primary courses committees established under the interim Curriculum and Examination Board is as follows:

Junior Cycle: Joint Management Body (Voluntary Schools), two representatives; Irish Vocational Education Association, one representative; Association of Secondary Teachers of Ireland, one representative; Teachers' Union of Ireland, one representative; Subject Association, one representative; Department of Education, two representatives; two-three nominees of the board with specialist expertise including where appropriate expertise in primary education.
Senior Cycle: As above with the following additions: National University of Ireland, one representative; University of Dublin, Trinity College, one representative.
Travel and subsistence allowances are paid to all members in accordance with the terms and rates applicable in the Civil Service.

As regards to primary and post-primary school teachers who may be members of these committees, substitution arrangements are a matter for individual teachers and their school authorities. My Department's regulations do not, in the normal course, provide for paid substitution in respect of occassional brief absence of teachers from school duties such as attendance at meetings of these course committees.

asked the Minister for Education the most recent figures in regard to the numbers involved in adult education in community/comprehensive schools and second level vocational education committee schools under (a) number of schools, (b) costs per school to the Exchequer and (c) unit costs of adult education in community/comprehensive and VEC second level schools.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke)
Speaker.P: Adult education may be formal or non-formal. Formal adult education is that for which students are enrolled; by contrast non-formal adult education is that for which none of the learners is enrolled or registered. Within these constraints the following are the most recent figures available. In the school year 1984-85, 218 vocational schools and 38 community/comprehensive schools provided courses in adult education for 77,304 and 36,835 participants, respectively. The data excludes students following part time courses such as apprenticeships and professional/technical courses. The cost of adult education courses is not readily available in respect of individual schools; but adult education courses, apart from literacy and community education are, in the main, expected to be self financing. Separate unit costs in respect of adult education courses are not available.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Vocational Education.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if the vocational education committees are required to provide education to travellers and prisoners; the number of VEC's which provide such educational services; and the cost to each VEC.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke)
Speaker.P: While the vocational education Acts lay down certain duties for VEC's in relation to the provision of continuation and technical education, the Acts do not require that particular groups such as travellers or prisoners be specifically catered for.
Information available to my Department indicates that there are 28 VEC's involved in educating travellers in training centres and eight VEC's involved in providing education services to prisons.

MainHeading.P: Because of the method of financing the activities of vocational education committes data are not available to my Department on the cost of these services to each VEC.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - School Management Boards Representation.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the levels of representation provided for parent representatives on the management boards of primary schools, secondary schools, community/ comprehensive schools, vocational schools and community colleges.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke)
Speaker.P: The levels of representation provided for parents on the management boards of schools are generally as follows:

row.entry: Two parents representatives on a board totalling six or eight members, depending generally on the size of the school.
These are privately owned and managed and there is no official requirement to have management boards. Where boards have been set up they usually have two parents representatives.
There is no provision for parents representatives.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke)

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Books and Library Materials Grants.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. Higgins Mr. M. Higgins
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the grants which are being paid towards the purchase of books and other library materials and services in secondary, community-comprehensive and second level vocational educational committee schools.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke)
Speaker.P: My Department operate a specific scheme of aid towards the cost of school books for necessitous pupils in post-primary schools. The amount of money available under this scheme in 1987 is £1,605,000.

Apart from this particular scheme the Department does not designate specific allocations for the purchase of books, library materials and services in its overall distribution of funds to post-primary schools. It is at the discretion of the management authorities of each type of school to allocate funds for the materials and services referred to in the question.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Wexford VEC Financial Allocation.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if her attention has been drawn to the underpayment of Wexford town Vocational Educational Committee under the maintenance heading by £19,000 for the year 1987; if she will immediately make up the shortfall; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke)
Speaker.P: I am aware of the claim by the town of Wexford VEC that they have been underpaid by £19,000 under the maintenance heading. I do not accept this contention. asked the Minister for Education whether finance has been allocated for improvements at Aillebrack national school and Bally-conneelly national school, Connemara, County Galway; and if so, when it is expected the work will commence.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke)
Speaker.P: My Department has agreed to grant-aid improvement schemes at both Aillebrack and Ballyconneely national school, County Galway.

In October 1986 the authorities of Aillebrack national school were authorised to invite tenders for the works proposed at this school. They subsequently forwarded one tender and were advised that it would be necessary for them in accordance with normal practice to seek other tenders. When this aspect of the matter has been satisfactorily dealt with, the authorities will be authorised to proceed with the works.

In March 1987 the authorities of Ballyconneely national school were authorised to accept a tender for the works proposed there. It is understood that the arrangement is that the works will be carried out during the summer vacation period. When the works have been satisfactorily completed in each case, the appropriate grants will be paid.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Pre-Employment Courses.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if she will give an account of pre-employment courses from their inception to date under the following headings (a) the types of schools, (b) the number of schools, (c) the numbers of teachers, (d) the numbers of pupils, by gender that participated, or were allowed to participate in these courses; whether any external or other forms of evaluation of these courses has been carried out; and whether theories of career choice were incorporated in formulating, implementing and evaluating these courses.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke)
Speaker.P: Available data as requested by the Deputy in respect to pre-employment courses, from their inception in 1976-77 until they were superseded by the Vocational Training and Preparation Programme in 1984-85, are contained in the attached tabular statement.

One of the objectives in formulating the programmes was to develop in participants the ability to plan and make life and career decisions. In their implementation the various elements of the programmes, vocational studies, preparation for working life and general studies were knit together to provide the participants with the knowledge and skills to move from school to work. (For example work experience was used as a means of broadening the awareness of participants to the variety of work available to them.) The programmes were the subject of ongoing evaluation by the Department's Inspectorate and Psychological Service in consultation with school and other authorities.
